clinical_study.brief_title: Dynamic Plantar Microvascular Skin Response to Compressive Loads in At-risk Diabetic and Healthy Control: a Pilot Study
clinical_study.official_title: Dynamic Plantar Microvascular Skin Response to Compressive Loads in At-risk Diabetic and Healthy Control

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this pilot study is to compare the dynamic response of microcirculation in the skin on the bottom of the big toe after applying controlled plantar stress in 25 diabetic subjects with a history of foot ulcer and 25 age-matched healthy controls to better understand the role of local hypoxia in neuropathic foot ulceration in subjects with diabetes.
The investigators hypothesize that if they apply a gait simulating load to the plantar foot and measure microvascular function, diabetic individuals will demonstrate an increased delay in reestablishing microvascular flow compared to healthy individuals.

primary_outcome.time_frame: approximately 2.75 minutes after start of collection protocol
primary_outcome.description: The time between removal of occluding pressure and the initiation of the post-occlusive hyperemic response as measured by laser Doppler.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2.75 seconds after start of collection protocol
secondary_outcome.description: The time interval between the start of post-occlusive hyperemic response and when the response curve reaches the baseline, or reference, flow level as measured by laser doppler.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At least 2.75 seconds after the start of collection protocol.
secondary_outcome.description: The time interval between the start of the post-occlusive hyperemic response and the time to reach maximum flow as measured by laser doppler

arm_group.description: Diabetic individuals with a history of previous plantar ulcer and a high risk of developing a foot ulceration
Non-diabetic, healthy individuals with low risk of developing a neurogenic foot ulcer

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- between ages 40 and 75
- history of diabetic neuropathic plantar ulcer (test subjects)
- no history of diabetes (control subjects)
- no peripheral sensory neuropathy (control subjects)
Exclusion Criteria:
- amputation or surgery on right Great Toe
